channel.title: Netty or Mina?
channel.description: I was wondering what you guys prefer when it comes to networking? If you want, give some pros/cons about them. I'm doing this because I want to see what others have used and think is a great networking library to work with.

item.title: Netty or Mina?
item.dc:creator: @matzie matzie
item.description:
@matzie wrote:

[quote=“Pwnd, post:15, topic:541525”]Look how butthurt everyone is.

Use what YOU think is best. One’s opinion is just an opinion. Try it out for yourself. See what best fits your application’s needs. Benchmark it. It might mean writing more code, but if you’re actually that dedicated to what is best for your application, then you’ll figure it out.[/quote]
very well put!
It depends on the application. You should do the research on each of them. If you need something you have control over every aspect, use netty. if you need something that is self managing, and just there to be there - mina. That’s what i have accumulated from the previous posts.

Read full topic

item.title: Netty or Mina?
item.dc:creator: @ExtremeX-Scape Ryley
item.description:
@ExtremeX-Scape wrote:

sinisoul:

If you don’t like verbose then why are you using java

^^

Netty is far superior than MINA, even more so that MINA is no longer actively maintained. The Netty project has been overhauled since 3.x to again address some of the anti-patterns and boilerplate required in any implementation. The ongoing effort paid off. They are once again going to address some more issues in the upcoming 5.x

Graham described most of the major points nicely.

Read full topic

item.title: Netty or Mina?
item.dc:creator: @Graham Graham
item.description:
@Graham wrote:

Ashi:

Mina also manages most of the pipeline stuff for you.

I don’t know where you have got this misconception that the way the pipeline works in Netty is different to how things work in MINA… IoFilterChain in MINA is (very nearly) completely analogous to ChannelPipeline in Netty. The only difference is that MINA enforces that you have a single IoHandler at the end of the pipeline (with the rest of it being composed of IoFilters), whereas Netty does not have a distinction between IoHandler and IoFilter - their functionality is rolled into a single ChannelHandler interface.

Ashi:

Opinions not valid unless you can actually back up that the pipeline is worth something. I’m pretty sure Mina simplifies what Netty over complicated.

The pipeline allows you to separate decoding packets from the logic that handles them. You can also have several different decoders in your pipeline for different types of packet, or decode a single packets in a sequence of several stages. It leads to cleaner code, and you can re-use code by mixing and matching existing decoders/encoders.

For example, if you wanted to read textual data from the client line by line, you can simply add the built-in DelimiterBasedFrameDecoder to the pipeline first, configured to split the incoming data by a newline character (\n), and then add the built-in StringDecoder, which will decode the array of bytes into a String (with an encoding such as UTF-8). Finally, your custom handler at the end of the pipeline would end up dealing with String objects, thus separating the handling logic from the decoding/encoding logic.

Of course, MINA has the exact same support for this kind of design in its IoFilterChain class, as I discussed above.

Ashi:

I don’t think Netty has session attributes either.

Netty 3 supports attaching a single object to a ChannelHandlerContext.

Netty 4 and above have got support for multiple attributes per channel again (in a rather nice type-safe manner) - see http://netty.io/4.0/api/io/netty/util/AttributeMap.html (which Channel, ChannelHandlerContext, etc. implement).

It’s generally very rare to need to use them anyway - most people use Netty in a manner such that you need separate instances of your codecs for each channel anyway (in fact for some classes e.g. FrameDecoder (now known as ByteToMessageDecoder in Netty 4+) this is enforced), in which case you can just use fields in your codec class to store state.

Ashi:

Mina also has a much better design

The author of both Netty and MINA (Trustin Lee) seems to imply Netty addresses some design issues in MINA (and thus has a better design) in this StackOverflow answer:
“Some of those features were integrated into the core too tightly to be removed even if they are not needed by a user. In Netty, I tried to address such design issues while retaining the known strengths of MINA.”
(http://stackoverflow.com/a/2000128/15755)

From having used both, I definitely prefer Netty.

Read full topic

item.title: Netty or Mina?
item.dc:creator: @Nothing1 -Nothing
item.description:
@Nothing1 wrote:

[quote=“Bl3nd, post:16, topic:541525”]Thanks for everyones thoughts and opinions. I may just go with netty but for me (a noob at programming) its just really hard to get the concept behind what I need for a rs framework. Ive looked at other works but because they are with the outdated netty it doesnt really help for me. (Im trying to use netty 4.x version)

I know I need a pipeline, decoder, encoder and a handler but how many decoders/encoders does a server usually need…

P.s. I also read the beginners guide for 4.x[/quote]
The netty 4.x is very similar to the 3.5, a lot of things have been renamed so you might have little trouble finding the classes / methods you need.

Usually a server only needs one encoder, decoder and login decoder. Login decoder is the default decoder for when clients open connection because the first data they send is the login data, after you have decoded and handled the login data properly you need to replace logindecoder with the game packet decoder.

On topic: I prefer Netty because it has always been more efficient on my servers and I’ve became really familiar with it so creating networking for any application is really easy for me.

Read full topic

item.title: Netty or Mina?
item.dc:creator: @lothy Lothy
item.description:
@lothy wrote:

[quote=“Ashi, post:13, topic:541525”]Mina also manages most of the pipeline stuff for you.

You really don’t need the raw pipeline access that Netty allows.[/quote]
Define ‘you’. There are plenty of people working on plenty of projects that make great use of netty precisely because it does give them that fine-grained control over encoding and decoding inbound/outbound streams.
You probably don’t need that functionality, and that’s fair enough, but plenty of people do.

And I hate to break it to you but MINA is dead. It hasn’t seen a stable release since October 2012. Evidently it has been put out to pasture.

Read full topic

item.title: Netty or Mina?
item.dc:creator: @Ashi Ashi
item.description:
@Ashi wrote:

[quote=“Lothy, post:11, topic:541525”]‘Pipeline crap’?

You’re joking right? The pipeline is one of netty’s most powerful features.[/quote]
Opinions not valid unless you can actually back up that the pipeline is worth something. I’m pretty sure Mina simplifies what Netty over complicated.

Mina also has a much better design and designed to be easy to use.
Mina also manages most of the pipeline stuff for you.

You really don’t need the raw pipeline access that Netty allows.

Read full topic

item.title: Netty or Mina?
item.dc:creator: @Ashi Ashi
item.description:
@Ashi wrote:

[quote=“Lothy, post:6, topic:541525”][quote author=xx matty xx link=topic=660396.msg4415936#msg4415936 date=1395928134]
Mina. Netty is for kiddies.
[/quote]
Do explain. Last I heard Netty was more feature rich, performs better, and is at least as well-maintained by the authors in terms of release cycle as mina is.
There’s nothing ‘kiddy’ about it.[/quote]
With Mina you don’t have to deal with the pipeline crap. It also handles the majority for you so you don’t have to do a lot of the work.
I don’t think Netty has session attributes either.

Read full topic

item.title: Netty or Mina?
item.dc:creator: @lothy Lothy
item.description:
@lothy wrote:

[quote=“Rodgerwilco, post:7, topic:541525”]Lets argue over something written by the same guy. :palm:
Mina and Netty both have to ability to be event driven so I don’t want to hear that nonsense either. Lothy is correct, Netty is considered better.[/quote]
Written by the same guy, but Mina through its Apache Foundation ownership would certainly attract attention and cause people to give it strong consideration (which is fair enough).

I still think the release cycle is what matters. In terms of functionality they’re comparable. Netty apparently performs better, but this isn’t a dealbreaker/dealmaker. Whether one API feels clunkier than the other is something that I can’t say (I haven’t worked with Mina for years).

But yeah, being written by the same guy doesn’t preclude discussing the merits of each.

Read full topic
